After that...I might call it quits and stop writing for the general. There is other stuff I need to work on. Never say never, but at the very least if I do "retire" I want to go out with a bang and give you guys one last piece of writing.

Anonymous Wed 14 Oct 2020 10:17:00 No.33394799 Report
Quoted By:
>>33392803
I assume that many things that wild animals do would come through in anthros as little mannerisms and similar things. The more unhygienic and/or embarrassing ones would likely be something that kids do but would learn to grow out of it as they got older. I think a lot of people don't realize how much of the little things that humans do are small leftover bits from our older primate ancestors, plenty of which can be seen as much more overt and extreme versions of what we do in other currently existing primates. There's no reason they wouldn't still go through heat in the same way humans haven't stopped having periods just because we're smart now. As far as promiscuity vs loyalty goes, humans come from one of the most promiscuous groups in the animal kingdom and managed to become (comparatively) very monogamous, and considering how promiscuity tends to get more common in lower intelligence populations it certainly appears as though becoming more intelligent results in a more chaste society. Thus, in all likelihood, most anthro populations would end up becoming much less promiscuous than their wild animal counterparts in much the same way humans have. However, that also has the added side effect of reversing humans being comparatively monogamous since most animals are already moreso than non-human primates and as such would probably end up seeing humans as quite whorish. As others already pointed out, outliers would absolutely exist, but it's not unlikely that anthros would apply that humans in thinking that they'd probably get cheated on by a human, with varying responses were they to actually get cheated on, usually more extreme than seen in humans.

>>33396254
Talk out the parts you don't like.
Bad punctuation and grammar will trip you up far quicker that way, and your dialogue/internal narration will feel more natural.
The downside is that, if you're like me, your second and third person voice may feel dryer during the first draft.

Anonymous Wed 14 Oct 2020 13:34:50 No.33396347 Report
Quoted By:
>>33396254
If you're looking for advice, here's how I do it: Write it anyway. Doesn't matter if it sounds awkward or reads like shit; just get it on the page. The you can move on to the next part, instead of being stuck, and your motivation won't drain because you're making zero progress. Then, once you're editing or when there's a natural stop between scenes/chapters/whatever, you go back and rewrite what doesn't work. By that point you might have a much better idea of where everything's going, and the tone in general, which can help you through that difficult part. Writing down literally anything, moving on and then coming back, is the best way I've found to avoid writer's block and motivation-draining lack of progress

Anonymous Wed 14 Oct 2020 15:38:45 No.33397647 Report
Quoted By: >>33397758 >>33397796
>>33383284
It's not about popularity, or really even recognition; it's the acknowledgement--especially approval--that's uplifting. It's not about generating a ton of buzz so much as just knowing you and your story aren't being rejected entirely. When a writer can't get a n y opinions about their work, whether a single line from an Anon to the effect of "I liked/hated it," or the oft-desired 2k-word critique of professional veracity, there's nothing that'll grip the RSD so painfully than no comment at all. If you've nobody you can show your work to at all, and Anons who will DM you asking for links to your stories won't even return questions as to whether they're so much as reading it, like it, whatever, how do I know if I should continue applying myself to it, or even continue my venture into creative writing at all? When writers suffer from conflating silence with absolute, unremitting feelings of rejection, they're strumming lifetime-spanning chords of self-doubt and pain that train them out of the enjoyment they used to love about creative writing at all, even when they've a history of high marks and praise for their irl short story submissions, screeds, essays, and what-not.

So, remember those whingey faggots that bitched about comments section-level appraisals from Anons who just wanted their favorite writers to know they appreciated their work? Yeah, ignore them; they're retards that don't know what they actually need, or have clearly never felt that rejection. Literally, even four-star comments with maybe a line or two of praise, or arbitrary complaints with selectively extractable crumbs of applicable criticism, are each so much better than being in a vacuum, alone with one's own runaway thoughts and feelings of failure and doubt. I also will never understand writers who DO know that pain, but who also make it later through sheer tenacity, never paying it forward when they observe that struggle in others.

>>33383459
>>33383376
Very, very well said.

If you have anyone irl or an e-bud with an eye for writing, you might try sharing a hidden PB link with them first for their thoughts and some critique. I know it can be tempting to pull up the curtain now, before the dust has settled around your work, but I promise, afterward, you'll be very glad you waited until having all your ducks in a row before sharing your magnum opus with the world. If you've held to an ideal release plan until now, I implore you to stick to it; I want you to get the biggest, possible hit from that final "Submit" click. It'll mean a lot to you, and your peers. But if you need to a little body exposition out of the way, you should definitely show off your work with some trustworthy peeps, especially those with experience.

I'm very surprised you don't know this feeling then. You must have immense confidence in your work. I think as artists/writers you're innately familiar with the actual crafting process of your piece, so you can better see its flaws and shortcomings. You then think "ah fuck I bet my audience can see how hacked together this scene is," but the fact is, 90% of the time, they can't. Still, the worry haunts you, so when sharing, it's easy to just instantly acknowledge any potential criticism.

It's just a natural thing for a lot of creators.

Anonymous Wed 14 Oct 2020 23:48:41 No.33405716 Report
Quoted By: >>33405728 >>33405900 >>33406019 >>33406546
>>33405263
Top pick:
>My Obsession
https://pastebin.com/MWchqEnk
and its sequel
>Altruistic Intent
https://pastebin.com/9DB0eB6p
A couple of other great picks:
>The Leaves of Fall
https://pastebin.com/gyfAjY5M
https://pastebin.com/TZGKfv3q
>Today's Demons are Tomorrow's Angels
https://pastebin.com/g4z5hZKn
My biggest complaint with "My Obsession" is that it isn't longer, not just because I didn't want it to end but also because some parts of the story felt like they advanced way too quick. Despite that it's still the best story I've ever read from /hmofa/ and I'm jealous of everyone that gets to read it for the first time since I never can again. Would recommend reading as soon as you have the time to finish it in one sitting (should be no more than a couple of hours).
"Altruistic Intent" is a very different story, though is actually a direct continuation of the above, however it isn't finished so do with that what you will. It does seem like it's solved most of the issues I had with "My Obsession" though.
"The Leaves of Fall" was highly engaging through almost every second of reading, though it does have some extremely glaring flaws. Would recommend just reading when you get a chance (to finish it in one sitting you'd have to dedicate a free day to it).
"Today's Demons are Tomorrow's Angels" is honestly just a very solid story the whole way through and what few problems I do have with it are relatively minor gripes. Would recommend reading maybe after work, should probably be five or six hours, still better to do in one sitting.
That being said, these are some of the best stories I've ever read, so don't let me frontloading the issues I have with them stop you from reading.
